text:
Your fleet fruitlessly attempts to raise the station, and predictably receive's no response.
A team is deployed to the station as a secondary measure. You watch from the feeds of the crew as the proceed to comb throughout the station for anything useful.

A few hours pass before you receive a new report, indicating hardly anything valuable could be found; the station indeed had been rather thoroughly combed through. The only standout mention was the indication that someone had been staying on the station until recently, and all indications pointed to them departing towards the gas giant Raven in search of something.

After a brieft moment, the connection resolves and a mercenaries visage stares back at you. 

"Ah, hello there! Are you in need of the skills of mercenaries with -real- talent?"

Much like your last encounter, the faceplate of the $nex_mercRank greets you. This time, however, $nex_mercHisOrHer voice cuts the silence first.

"I have no business with you."

"Affirmative. I'll gather the crew."

A small band of warcraft join up with your $shipOrFleet a short period later.

"It's been a pleasure. Don't be a stranger."

You accept $hisOrHer decision professionally and, after exchanging a few pleasantries, cut the comm link.
I don't do charity work, Commander. Find me when your finances are in order.
Crimson allows you to finish your tirade. There is a brief silence before they chuckle creepily, cutting the comm.

The $personRank stares at you, faceplate masking their true reaction.

"Word about people like you spreads fast, $playerName. I'll see you very soon."

The comm link is cut before you have a chance to respond.

text:
Your standard comms request gives no return. If there is a comms network, or even an emergency survival unit on the surface, it's either damaged or can't make a connection.  

Your comms officer tries more unconventional workarounds, from a suite of ancient standards used to ping drifting Domain-era relics to the latest suite of underworld methods that would earn a stern look from any honest customs officer; lossy but easily mistaken for background noise by sensor grids. All attempts are fruitless.

"$PlayerSirOrMadam. We might have to make contact the old fashioned way," your comms officer reports apologetically.

Beneath your feet, the deck trembles, and the unfamiliar sound of wind shear fills the air as the autoshuttle pierces through $fullName's dense atmosphere. 

"Fifteen minutes out," your shuttle pilot informs you through your earpiece, "Keep your EVA helmets on for now, cabin's not yet pressurized. The ride's pretty rough – wouldn't want you bumping your head against something before we touch down."

With a click, the radio communication ends. The cabin lights momentarily flicker due to a particularly forceful jolt, but then the gusty wind subsides, and the roaring engines settle into a steady cruising rhythm. The sound of air hissing through your helmet drowns out all other noises.

Below, lies the verdant expanse of $fullName.

With no obvious landing area to see, the shuttle touches down in a burned out section of field. The rear door of the shuttle drops, allowing you and your entourage to step out into the humid $fullNameian air. While it's guaranteed at least someone has seen you land here, no one has arrived to greet you. Yet.

An expansive sea of verdant grass extends as far as the eye can see, encompassing the surroundings in its vibrant embrace. Sporadically scattered across the terrain, sizable yet squat mounds interrupt the green expanse in irregular arrangements. In the distance, what you surmise to be the settlement looms, it's ugly grey buildings bordered by a low
wall.

In time a small convoy of vehicles approach the shuttle, and a cadre of soldiers hop out, weapons slung, trudging towards you.

"Hello there, unfamiliar face. What has brought you to this area?" he asks in a friendly tone, nonchalantly shifting his gaze between you and your companions. His attitude appears relaxed and informal, yet you can discern that behind this facade lies a weathered warrior.

"Mmm...let's hear about it back in the city, yes?" he says, motioning for you and your men to follow.

You and your crew are loaded into one of the vehicles the soldiers brought along. They eye you with detached curiousity, but are not much for conversation, making the trip back rather uneventful. 

As you draw near what appears to be a checkpoint, you note a trooper leaning against the wall of a two-story complex. The lower level of the building seems to house shops; the signs painted on the closed metal gates suggest they offer items like local bread and other edibles. Above them, a couple of flats can be seen, their windows also tightly closed with shutters. He stands, waving off some security drones, and opens a gate that allows the convoy to pass into the city proper.
Finally, the convoy comes to a halt, and the men sharing a vehicle at you nod, gesturing towards a building in the distance.
